caption: One of the best museum in Paris. Unbelievable and breath-taking. Its a must if you like medieval history

Treasures of the Medieval Age. Big draw: The Lady and the Unicorn Tapestries. I did not photograph them, instead purchased a magnet depicting my favorite panel. The Boutique is replete with books, toys, jewelry. A MUST when in Paris. If you choose a weekday, go early. It is a popular place for students of all grades.

Beautiful historic museum in Paris, the building itself goes back to the middle ages with extensions from modern periods. The museum contains historical artifacts that goes back to the middle ages in the west and the east. So there is a lot of statues and stone carvings, christian golden elements, wooden carvings, mural carpets... it takes time to visit all the collection but its really worth it.

The Musée de Cluny has a wondrous collection of tapestries from the 1500s called The Lady and the Unicorn. The 6 tapestries, 5 senses + 1, acquired in 1882, is considered one of the great masterpieces of Western art. The other exhibits are similarly captivating, ancient artifacts demonstrating the activities and creativity of the times. The museum docents are very kind and helpful. There is renovation so not all rooms were open but this is a must see in Paris.

How do I even begin about the fascinating collection in this museum? Musée de Cluny is an absolute treasure, with its incredible tapestries and reliquaries. I spent three hours here, completely captivated by the exhibits. I accidentally booked a tour about the heroes and heroines of the Middle Ages that was in French. While I was eager to attend, I hadn't realized it would only be offered in French. When I informed the staff, they quickly accommodated me by finding another engaging experience within the museum. It's a fascinating place with an amazing collection.
A really lovely museum! The Roman remains are stunning and they have a lovely collection

Recently renovated and rich collection of French medieval art. The unicorn tapestries are its star exhibit and they do really stand out for their beauty and grandeur. But there are quite a few things worth your time. The collection is not too big, and two hours is more than enough to enjoy the museum. A small cafe serves the basics and even has some tables in the courtyard to enjoy the Parisian summer.

Highlight of my paris trip. If you are into medieval art, this is for you. I came to see the unicorn tapestries. So now I have seen the blue ones at the cloisters in NY and the red ones in paris. They are breathe taking.
One of the best museums to visit in Paris. There are so many exquisite works displayed so beautifully. Above all, it is a manageable size. We spent over two hours and saw everything.

Hard one to rate to be honest, as the place is beautiful but when you go in you see that some works are hidden away behind the free standing walls and some parts aren’t in English and others are. You can get an audio guide for a 2€ but I only found that out once I was walking around inside the exhibition spaces. I feel it would be nicer to see more of the original building on the ground floor. It has free lockers for your bag but very few for big bags, so be mindful of that. Other than that the staff are nice and if you love medieval ages of France and surrounding areas, then it’s definitely worth your time! If not and you have a short time in Paris then I’d say avoid it. It does have a great gift shop tho!

The museum with religious exhibits offered an average experience. While it provided insight into various faiths, the presentation lacked the depth and engagement expected. Despite touching on significant themes, the overall impression fell short, leaving room for improvement in delivering a more compelling narrative.

Musee de Cluny has a vast collection of medieval treasures, including the fabulous Lady and the Unicorn tapestries. There are also many other beautifully preserved tapestries, along with religious sculptures, and statues from Notre Dame that were removed following the French Revolution.  I highly recommend a visit to the Musee de Cluny when you visit Paris.

This was an amazing museum however I have a few points 1. If you go in with a basic understanding of the middle ages, it's probably not enough to full understand the exhibits so study beforehand 2. I wish they had kept the museum in a more traditional and ancient style! You can see parts of the abbey and the exterior is beautiful, but they mixed modern and ancient inside and I feel like it doesn't do the place justice

If you are at all into the middle ages 16th century, particular non-secular items, this is a fantastic museum.  The visit is worth it just to see The Lady and the Unicorn tapestries. There are some truly amazing wood carved altar pieces from the 1500s that were maybe 4'x6'. The pieces there are generally religious oriented, but the craftsmanship is breathtaking.

I have been to the museum a few times, and always enjoy a return. The museum features a pleasant blend of Roman bath houses, and the medieval mansion built by monks on the same site. The collection of medieval art is also fantastic, but everyone loves the pièce de resistance, the tapestries of the woman with the unicorn (la dame à la licorne.)

A museum filled with many, many artefacts, most with a strong religious theme which may or may not be your thing. The lower level is an old Roman bath house. Information boards are in both French and English.
Of all the museums visited in Paris, the Cluny was my favorite! As a photo tells a thousand words, I’ll keep my review short and to the point.

Bought a ticket for first thing in the morning.  Some excellent examples of life and art starting from 1100 to 1600.  Well presented and easy to move around, not as crowded as many of the other sites.  Elevators and bathrooms on site.  All of the displays are in both French and English.  One of my favorite museums in Paris.

A magnificent collection of art of all forms from the Middle Ages. The display of each of the thousands of pieces is well thought out and permits the viewer to truly absorb the work. The piece de resistance is the room of 'The Lady and the Unicorn' pieces, huge tapestries which are amazing examples of their time and age. And of course entry is free on the first Sunday of the month, but it is well worth the time and entry fee to visit regardless. (And yes, there is a small cafe inside, along with many eateries outside.)

Spectacular. One of our favourite museums in Paris... Filled with beautiful pieces of art and history, and because it is so quiet you can really appreciate the building itself as well. A highlight of our trip.
I enjoyed this art museum.  Rick Steves raves about it, and it was fascinating.  A look back into history. Of course, the lady and the unicorn tapestry is the main attraction.

A lovely museum with a varied collection. But the key attraction and the absolute best room of the entire museum is undoubtedly the Lady abd the Unicorn tapestry room! As you come in you are surrounded by the set of six tapestries, lit up in the general darkness of the room. The amazing detail and the possibility to see it up close, to notice the tapestries referencing each other - it simply takes your breath away. This was a truly moving experience and I highly recommend it!

A delightful smaller museum that has been renovated very successfully. Plan at least two hours for a visit or you will feel rushed. The museum cafe is fairly priced at has tables in the beautiful courtyard.

A great museum filled with rich history and art almost marred by Fawlty towers-esque staff. One floor was inexplicably closed and when exploring the  other floor, again, inexplicably was told it would be closing as well. All museum guests ushered to the Cafe and courtyard- perhaps in an attempt to force them to purchase sodastream water and coffee from a machine I have only seen in 7/11. Once the next floor opened; there was a mad rush, and once waiting for this to subside we were then told it was closed again! Well all exits were blocked and staff then walked off to speak on walkie talkies whilst ignoring our pleas for access to the museum we had paid to enter. We were finally and graciously allowed access! By this point anything the staff did was obvious and thus annoying- slamming staff only access doors, lingering in narrow doorways or crossing in front of you on their patrols. Sad that my experience will have this annoyance attached. I would still recommend the museum as the information attached to each item is great, and the museum is well laid out.

It is a beautiful museum dedicated to the art and history of the Middle Ages. Here, you can admire an impressive collection of medieval sculptures, manuscripts, textiles, and jewelry. The building itself is an architectural treasure, with a particularly beautiful courtyard, where you can enjoy coffee from the museum cafeteria at a reasonable price.
Very nice museum and great for seniors.  I brought my 82 YO mom here and she had a great time here.  Great collections they have.
Beautiful museum is a preserved church. They have great temporary exhibits as well as permanent ones. You only need about an hour to see everything.  very worth the trip!

A vast collection of mostly French masterpieces from the Middle Ages period including sculptures,  paintings, precious artifacts of all kinds etc. inside spaces originally belonging to the Cluny Monacal Order. The Lady of the Unicorn tapestries are absolutely enchanting and visually striking in a perfectly list special room, enough by themselves to justify the visit. The set of 6 represents an allegory of the 5 senses or virtues while the last one is more mysterious and may represent a higher spiritual sixth sense.

The museum is a great source of information about the medieval times and is certainly worth a visit. The people are helpful and even though some rooms were closed there was plenty to see, from tapestries to stairs and woodcarving. You can have coffee in the courtyard and they had a delicious dessert with soft cheese and chestnut. The only part that could be improved is the signposting which often has you wander around a lot. It would be nice which the general direction of travel is, and where there are some extra rooms to visit.

This was one of the most unique museums I've been to so far in Paris. While it's more of a mideval art museum (that should be mentioned before hand) it did not let me down.  I'm a history efficianado and was impressed by the amount of Christian art, tapestries, and especially the books.  I do appreciate the accessibility.

Love the room with the lady and the unicorn, so stunning to see the tapestry in person, so large and well preserved! Enjoyed learning and the experience of the medieval period and artwork. Excellent wall description by historical order. Highly recommended!
Cool museum if you like the middle ages in general, wish there were more swords and armors.

So many Paris museums are unbelievably crowded which makes it hard to appreciate the art. This place didn’t have the same level of famous work as the louvre or l’orangerie, but it was peaceful and incredibly interesting. Would recommend going if you have a bit extra time in Paris!!

Mind bending collection beautifully presented, in an equally great location. The exhibition design prioritizes our experience with these amazing artworks/objects over wall graphics and infotainment. Thank god there are no video screens telling idiots how to think. Blissfully empty at 9:30 AM and it was by far my favorite art experience in Paris and maybe the past 5 years.

Very nice public museum with always temporary exhibitions. The building has been recently renovated, the selection of pieces of art are of a very high level. It retraced the middle age periode with explanation of what art comes from where. The master piece is at the end of the visit with La Dame à la Licorne, a 5 pieces of tapisserie. It worth a visit!

The collection of Medieval artifacts mostly from Christian sites is amazing and a treasure trove that broadens my understanding of early Christianity. Pieces are in incredible shape. I love the museum guiding visitors through various themes of artifacts as I got more insights into European culture from many centuries prior. This museum is a gem for those of us who love to see historical objects . Plus the Roman Baths of the 2nd or 3rd century are well preserved giving more insights to our European history.

What is most impressive is how big it is inside, and how deep underground in Paris is. The collection of art pieces is truly something. I recommend going there with a guide to get more context, especially surrounding the cristal sections.

Very beautiful building. Hidden museum without of interesting religious pieces.  The Cluny Museum - National Museum of the Middle Ages is located in the heart of Paris.  The museum unfolds on the site of the ancient thermal baths - do not miss the spectacular frigidarium whose vaults culminate at 14m high - and in the medieval hotel of the abbots of Cluny, a jewel of the flamboyant Gothic style. Since 2018, a new pavilion has welcomed visitors in resolutely contemporary architecture.  Nearly 1,600 masterpieces of medieval art are presented in a chronological journey that sweeps more than 1000 years of history.  Among the jewels of the museum's collections: the famous tapestries of the Lady with the unicorn, the heads of the kings of Judah from Notre-Dame Cathedral or stained glass windows of the Holy Chapel, and also one of the most beautiful collections of Limousin enamel.
